importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky earned international acclaim as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion in November 2007, establishing him as a top young talent in chess.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
The New York Times hired Naroditsky as a chess columnist in 2022, marking a significant milestone in his public influence and media presence.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Naroditsky’s career spanned from his early achievements in 2007 to his death in 2025, illustrating a long and impactful journey in chess as a player, educator, and public figure.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29.
He was a world-renowned chess player who earned the grandmaster title before high school and won national championships at a young age.
Naroditsky became a prominent educator and media figure, publishing chess manuals and contributing to Chess Life and the New York Times.
He built a massive online following with nearly half a million YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers, where he livestreamed games and taught accessible chess strategies.
The Charlotte Chess Center, where he served as head coach, and the International Chess Federation both publicly mourned his passing.
A moment of silence was observed at the 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis in his honor.
He is remembered as a beloved mentor and community pillar who inspired countless players globally through his passion and teaching.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster born in the San Francisco Bay Area, died at age 29. He earned international acclaim as a youth champion and became a grandmaster before high school, later earning a bachelor’s degree in history from Stanford University. A passionate educator and media figure, Naroditsky gained widespread popularity through livestreams on YouTube and Twitch, where he taught accessible chess strategies to millions. His contributions to chess education and community were widely recognized, with institutions like the Charlotte Chess Center, Stanford, the International Chess Federation, and the New York Times honoring him. A moment of silence was observed at the 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis in his memory, reflecting his deep impact on the global chess community.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
